issues.description: The UML/problem statement declares RollerCoaster.numberOfLoopings as type int, but the solution implementation declares the attribute and its constructor parameter as double (RollerCoaster.numberOfLoopings: double, RollerCoaster(String, char, double)). This creates a structural type mismatch: students following the UML will implement numberOfLoopings as int, while the provided solution uses double. The mismatch also affects constructors/getters (solution.getNumberOfLoopings() returns double). This inconsistency can confuse students about the correct type to use and may cause automated checks (that expect int per UML) to fail or require unnecessary workarounds.
issues.suggested_fix: Make the type of numberOfLoopings consistent with the UML/problem statement. Preferably change the solution (and any template hints) so RollerCoaster.numberOfLoopings is of type int, update the RollerCoaster constructor to take int numberOfLoopings, and make getNumberOfLoopings() return int. Alternatively, if double is intended, update the UML/problem statement to specify double for numberOfLoopings so all artifacts match.
